details.title: Analysis of Incomplete, Censored Data in Competing Risks Models With Generalized Exponential Distributions
details.standardTitle: Analysis of Incomplete, Censored Data in Competing Risks Models With Generalized Exponential Distributions

p: Ammar M. Sarhan received the B.S. (1985), and M.S. (1989) degrees in Mathematics from the Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt; and the Ph.D (1996) degree in Mathematical Statistics from the Institute of Mathematics, Gdansk University, Poland. Originally, he was working as an associate professor of Statistics in the Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt. But now, he is working as a professor of Statistics under a contract with the Department of Statistics and Operation Research, College of Science, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia. His research interests include Statistical Inferences, Reliability Analysis, Competing Risks Models, Statistical Computing, and Multivariate distributions.

details.abstract: This paper presents estimates of the parameters included in a competing risks model in the presence of incomplete & censored data. We consider the case when the competing risks have generalized exponential distributions. The maximum likelihood procedure is used to derive point, and asymptotic confidence interval estimations of the unknown parameters. The relative risks due to each cause of failure are investigated. A set of real data is used to test the hypothesis that the causes of failure follow exponential distributions against that they follow generalized exponential distributions

context.text: The parametric setup is studied assuming that the competing risks follow different lifetime distributions such as exponential, gamma, and Weibull; see for example Berkson & Elveback [1], Cox [2], David & Moeschberger [3], Park [22], and Kundu & Sarhan [17].

context.text: Kundu & Basu [15] considered the same model studied by Miyakawa [21] under the assumption that every member of a certain target population either dies of a particular cause, say cancer, or by other causes.
The results presented in this paper generalize those given by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
This section illustrates whether the model studied here can better fit a real data set rather than the exponential distribution model studied by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
Our goal in this section is to show whether the model presented in this paper fits a real data set better than the exponential distribution model discussed by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
The work presented in this paper is mainly the continuation of the work presented by Mayakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
Mayakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15] analyzed the incomplete data in the presence of competing risks models assuming the lifetime distributions to be exponential for the different risks.

links.abstract: In reliability analysis, an investigator is often interested in the assessment of a specific risk in presence of other risk factors. It is well known as the competing risks problem in the statistical literature. In this paper, we consider the analysis of incomplete data in the presence of competing risks among several groups. We mainly consider the latent failure times model formulation, and it is assumed that the lifetime distributions of the different latent failure times of a particular group...

context.text: The parametric setup is studied assuming that the competing risks follow different lifetime distributions such as exponential, gamma, and Weibull; see for example Berkson & Elveback [1], Cox [2], David & Moeschberger [3], Park [22], and Kundu & Sarhan [17].

references.title:
Analysis of incomplete sata in the presence of competing
risks among several groups
references.text: D. Kundu, A. Sarhan, "Analysis of incomplete sata in the presence of competing risks among several groups", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, pp. 262-269, 2006.

context.text: We use a real data set from Lawless [18] to test the exponential distribution against the generalized exponential distribution for fitting the data in this practical situation.
A real data set from Lawless [18] is analyzed for illustrative purposes in Section V, and we conclude the paper in Section VI.
For illustrative purpose, we consider in this section a real-life data set from Lawless ([18], p. 441).
A set of real data from Lawless [18] is used for illustrative purposes.

links.abstract: Parametric and nonparametric estimation methods are proposed for reliability characteristics of one failure mode under competing risks with incomplete data; some of the failure times are observed without observing the cause of failure. The efficiencies of these methods are discussed.

context.text: Maximum likelihood estimators, and the uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimators of the failure rates of different failure distributions of a competing risks model, under the assumption that the risks follow exponential distributions, are considered by Miyakawa [21].

Kundu & Basu [15] considered the same model studied by Miyakawa [21] under the assumption that every member of a certain target population either dies of a particular cause, say cancer, or by other causes.
The results presented in this paper generalize those given by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
This section illustrates whether the model studied here can better fit a real data set rather than the exponential distribution model studied by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
Our goal in this section is to show whether the model presented in this paper fits a real data set better than the exponential distribution model discussed by Miyakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
The work presented in this paper is mainly the continuation of the work presented by Mayakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15].
Mayakawa [21], and Kundu & Basu [15] analyzed the incomplete data in the presence of competing risks models assuming the lifetime distributions to be exponential for the different risks.

references.title:
Analysis of incomplete data
in competing risks model
references.text: M. Miyakawa, "Analysis of incomplete data in competing risks model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 33, pp. 293-296, 1984.

links.abstract: Consider a system which is made up of multiple components connected in a series. In this case, the failure of the whole system is caused by the earliest failure of any of the components, which is commonly referred to as competing risks. In certain situations, it is observed that the determination of the cause of failure may be expensive, or may be very difficult to observe due to the lack of appropriate diagnostics. Therefore, it might be the case that the failure time is observed, but its corre...

links.abstract: We express the joint entropy of order statistics in terms of an incomplete integral of the hazard function, and provide a simple estimate of the joint entropy of the type II censored data. Then we establish a goodness of fit test statistic based on the Kullback-Leibler information with the type II censored data, and compare its performance with some leading test statistics. A Monte Carlo simulation study shows that the proposed test statistic shows better powers than some leading test statistics...
